title: R43398
content: The federal government has been collecting educational statistics for over 150 years. The National Institute of Education (NIE) and the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) were established in the mid-1970s to centralize research efforts. In 1985, the NIE was replaced by the Office of Educational Research and Improvement (OERI). The Office of Educational Research and Improvement (OERI) replaced the National Institute of Education (NIE) in 1985. The Institute of Education Sciences (IES) took over in 2002 through the Education Sciences Reform Act, establishing IES as an independent research institute within the Department of Education. The National Board of Educational Sciences (NBES) advises the Director on institute policies, approves research priorities, and assesses progress for improvement. ESRA established three National Education Centers: NCER, NCES, and NCEE. P.L. 108-446 amended ESRA. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) was reauthorized, amending ESRA to include the National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER). P.L. 107-279 also enacted the Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA) and the National Assessment of Educational Progress Authorization Act (NAEPAA). ETAA provides grants for technical assistance activities, while NAEPAA authorizes a national assessment. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) authorizes national assessments in reading and mathematics for grades 4, 8, and 12. It led to the creation of an independent research institute and set standards for research. The Institute of Education Sciences (IES) operates independently with more freedom from the Department of Education. ESRA establishes oversight of IES through a technical panel and sets standards for educational research, including scientifically based research and valid evaluations. The House of Representatives and the Senate passed bills to reauthorize ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA, emphasizing methodological rigor in IES-supported research. Funding for these programs has continued through annual appropriations legislation. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA), ETAA, and NAEPAA aimed to amend provisions related to IES independence, research standards, technical assistance, evaluation, privacy protection, student assessment oversight, and IES accountability. ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA established programs and authorities aligned with P.L. 107-279. Title I of P.L. 107-279 is the Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA), which includes provisions authorizing IES, the NBES, and National Education Centers. IES, established under Part A of ESRA, aims to provide national leadership in education research by compiling statistics, conducting evaluations, and disseminating information to improve academic achievement and assess the effectiveness of education programs. The Institute of Education Sciences (IES) aims to provide national leadership in education research by compiling statistics, conducting evaluations, and disseminating information. The IES Director is appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate, selected from individuals with expertise in research, statistics, or evaluation in education. The Director is authorized to propose research priorities, establish review procedures, advise the Secretary on research matters, and ensure activities are objective and free of bias. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) established the National Board for Education Sciences (NBES) to advise the IES Director on policies, research priorities, funding decisions, and progress assessments. The NBES ensures that IES activities are objective and free from bias. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) established the National Board for Education Sciences (NBES) to advise the IES Director on policies, research priorities, funding decisions, and progress assessments. ESRA specifies requirements for the Board's composition, qualification, compensation, and travel expenses. IES consists of four research centers: NCER, NCES, NCEE, and NCSER, each headed by a Commissioner appointed by the Director for a term not exceeding six years. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) established the National Board for Education Sciences (NBES) to advise the IES Director on policies, research priorities, funding decisions, and progress assessments. ESRA specifies requirements for the Board's composition, qualification, compensation, and travel expenses. IES consists of four research centers: NCER, NCES, NCEE, and NCSER, each headed by a Commissioner appointed by the Director for a term not exceeding six years. The Commissioner of NCES is appointed by the President for a term of six years. Each research center has specific duties outlined in ESRA. Part B of ESRA authorizes NCER to sponsor research that ensures all children have access to high-quality education, improves student academic achievement, closes the achievement gap, and improves access to education. NCER, as outlined in ESRA, is responsible for maintaining peer-review processes, proposing research plans, ensuring research relevance to education practice and policy, and synthesizing research findings. The Commissioner of NCER is authorized to support national research and development centers focusing on various topics such as adult literacy, assessment, early childhood education, school improvement, education reform, teacher quality, and reading. Grants are awarded to address areas of national need. The Commissioner of NCER supports national research and development centers addressing areas of national need through competitive grants. Awards are given for up to five years, with the possibility of continuation grants for up to 10 years. Research plan includes basic and applied research, field-initiated research, and ongoing initiatives. At least 50% of funds are allocated for long-term research programs lasting five years. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) is authorized to collect and analyze education information and statistics to fund long-term research programs of at least five years. NCES's primary duty is to compile and disseminate education statistics from preschool through adulthood in an objective, neutral, and timely manner for practitioners, researchers, policymakers, and the public. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) compiles and disseminates education statistics for practitioners, researchers, policymakers, and the public. Other duties include publishing reports on statistics, setting standards for data systems, and comparing student achievement internationally. The Commissioner can award grants and contracts to carry out these duties. Certain data must be collected on various topics. ESRA specifies data collection on state and local education reform, early childhood school readiness, student achievement in reading, math, and science, school completions, dropouts, teaching practices, violence in schools, education financing, children's social and economic status, and educational technology. ESRA Part D authorizes NCEE to support data collection on various aspects of education, including student demographics, educational technology, early childhood programs, and school libraries. Data must be disaggregated by various factors to aid in decision-making. The National Center for Education Evaluation (NCEE) supports evaluation, technical assistance, and dissemination activities to facilitate educational and policy decision making. NCEE's mission includes conducting evaluations of federal education programs to determine their impact on student academic achievement and encouraging the use of scientifically valid education research. The National Center for Education Evaluation (NCEE) is authorized to award grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements to promote scientifically valid education research and evaluation in the United States. ESRA mandates that NCEE establish evaluation methodology, adhere to high standards, and conduct peer-reviewed evaluations, focusing on programs under Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The National Center for Education Evaluation (NCEE) is responsible for promoting valid education research and evaluations in the US, focusing on programs under Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The NCEE conducts evaluations and provides technical assistance through the Regional Educational Laboratories (REL) program, which carries out research, development, dissemination, and assistance activities to meet regional needs. The Director of the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) contracts with 10 RELs to serve children across the country, setting specific objectives and indicators to assess their performance. The Regional Educational Laboratories (RELs) provide training, technical assistance, and research on teaching methods, assessment tools, and curriculum frameworks for SEAs, LEAs, school boards, and state boards of education. They also facilitate communication between educational experts, school officials, teachers, parents, and librarians to support schools in developing educational plans. The Regional Educational Laboratories (RELs) work with school officials, teachers, parents, and librarians to develop plans to meet state education goals, survey regional needs, conduct research, and disseminate findings. The Commissioner of NCEE ensures independent evaluations of RELs and shares results with relevant committees. NCSER sponsors research to improve education for infants, toddlers, and children with disabilities. The National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) sponsors research to improve education for infants, toddlers, and children with disabilities, focusing on improving services under IDEA, identifying scientifically based practices, and evaluating the implementation of IDEA. The National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) focuses on improving education for children with disabilities by aligning state standards, addressing overidentification and underidentification of children with disabilities, improving personnel preparation, examining excess costs, and addressing the needs of limited English proficient children with disabilities through grants and research activities. The National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) is responsible for conducting research in line with NCER standards. NCSER synthesizes and disseminates special education research findings. ESRA Part F outlines provisions on prohibitions, confidentiality, data availability, performance management, staffing, and appropriations. $400 million was authorized for FY2003 for ESRA activities. Title II of P.L. 107-279, known as the Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA), authorizes grants for technical assistance, evaluation, and statewide data systems. Funding for these activities has continued through annual appropriations legislation since the authorities expired in FY2008. The Secretary can award grants for comprehensive centers in 10 regions to provide technical assistance to local entities. These centers work with SEAs, LEAs, and schools in their region, offering training, professional development, and disseminating information to improve academic achievement. The comprehensive centers provide technical assistance to local entities in 10 regions, focusing on improving academic achievement through training, professional development, and dissemination of information. Each center must coordinate activities with various agencies, establish an advisory board, and undergo independent evaluations. The Secretary can also award grants to SEAs for statewide longitudinal data systems. The Secretary can award grants to SEAs for statewide longitudinal data systems to manage student data efficiently and meet ESEA requirements. Funding was authorized for FY2003 and continued through annual appropriations legislation. The National Assessment of Educational Progress Authorization Act (NAEPAA) established the National Assessment Governing Board (NAGB) and charges the Commissioner of Education Statistics with conducting the National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP). NAEP includes a national assessment program, a state assessment program, a long-term trend study, and a trial urban district assessment program, focusing on student achievement in reading and mathematics for grades 4 and 8. The National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP) assesses student achievement in reading and mathematics every two years for grades 4 and 8. States can choose to participate in the program voluntarily, with the Assessment Board setting policy guidelines and including various stakeholders. The Assessment Board for the National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP) includes governors, state legislators, educators, and testing experts. Their duties include selecting subjects to assess, setting achievement levels, and ensuring assessments are valid and reliable. The Assessment Board for the National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP) is responsible for developing standards and procedures for assessing student academic achievement in grades 4, 8, and 12, ensuring the validity and reliability of assessment items, and establishing guidelines for reporting and disseminating results. They also oversee regional and national comparisons of student performance. The National Assessment Governing Board is responsible for developing standards and procedures for assessing student academic achievement in grades 4, 8, and 12, ensuring validity and reliability of assessment items, and overseeing regional and national comparisons of student performance. Funding for these activities has been authorized through annual appropriations legislation. During the 113th and 114th Congress, bills were passed to reauthorize ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA, amending provisions related to IES independence, research standards, evaluation, privacy protection, student assessment oversight, and IES accountability. Both H.R. 4366 and S. 227 aimed to give the Director of IES authority to accept. Both H.R. 4366 and S. 227 aimed to give the Director of IES authority to accept additional responsibilities from the Secretary, appoint the Commissioner of NCES, and ensure independence of NBES with practitioner board members. Both H.R. 4366 and S. 227 proposed changes to the appointment term of the IES Director, requiring consultation with the Director in procurement and performance management processes. Both H.R. 4366 and S. 227 proposed involving the Director of IES in contracting processes and establishing a peer review system for grants and agreements exceeding $100,000. The bills require that IES awards grants, contracts, and agreements through a peer review process. The bills proposed amending the definition of "scientifically based research standards" to "principles of scientific research." Research supported by IES would need to adhere to these principles, allowing for "strong claims of causal relationships" with research designs that eliminate competing explanations, including random assignment experiments. The bills emphasized that such designs are not limited to random assignment experiments. The bills proposed adjusting research priorities for IES, focusing on educational problems relevant to federal laws like ESEA, IDEA, and HEA. They aimed to improve early childhood, elementary, secondary, and postsecondary education quality and access. Specific priorities under current law would no longer be specified. The bills also aimed to eliminate the requirement for a minimum of 8 national research studies. The bills aimed to adjust research priorities for IES, focusing on educational issues related to federal laws like ESEA, IDEA, and HEA. They proposed eliminating the requirement for a minimum of 8 national research centers and specified the mission of RELs as conducting applied research, development, evaluation, and dissemination activities. The bills also aimed to ensure that RELs' work is responsive to the region's needs and limited the number of RELs to not more than 10. The bills aimed to adjust research priorities for IES, focusing on educational issues related to federal laws like ESEA, IDEA, and HEA. They proposed limiting the number of RELs to not more than 10 and giving authority to the Evaluation and Regional Assistance Commissioner to determine the appropriate number of RELs and reorganize laboratories based on performance indicators. Technical assistance responsibility would be assigned to ED-administered Comprehensive Centers. The bills proposed limiting the number of Comprehensive Center awards to 17, with the Secretary having authority to determine the appropriate number based on performance indicators. The bills proposed reducing the number of Comprehensive Center awards to 17, giving the Secretary the authority to adjust based on performance indicators. The bills also designated IES as the primary entity for research on federal education programs and allowed the Secretary to reserve a small percentage of funds for specific programs. The bills proposed consolidating funds for evaluations of programs authorized under ESEA, clarifying privacy protection for individuals in data collection, and amending the role of the National Assessment Governing Board. The bills aimed to consolidate funds for program evaluations under ESEA, clarify privacy protection in data collection, and amend the role of the National Assessment Governing Board to oversee and set policies for the NAEP. Evaluation of National Education Centers would be conducted by an independent entity tied to a performance management system for continuous improvement. The bills aimed to improve the effectiveness of IES activities by using measurable performance indicators to gauge progress and meet stakeholders' needs. Renewal of grants and agreements would be tied to progress on these indicators, with the Director authorized to renew support for research centers without competition for up to two years. Both bills propose renewing authority for up to two years for the Statistics Commissioner, Evaluation and Regional Assistance Commissioner, and Special Education Research Commissioner. Recipients of renewal awards must show progress in meeting ESRA's performance management system requirements. Both bills propose renewing authority for up to two years for key commissioners and require recipients to demonstrate progress in meeting ESRA's performance management system. They also mandate public reporting of grant information and authorize specific appropriations for ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA for FY2015 through FY2020. The bills propose authorizing appropriations for the RELs at 16.13% of funds appropriated for ESRA, rather than at a fixed amount for FY2003 and subsequent years as per current law.
